ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained some understanding of the nuances of how to get published.
I could hear about useful things in the actual publication process.
How to tackle a research paper; how to approach data collection; how to expand my thoughts about an issue.
Some useful advice here and there on the research process... and fun chance to discuss other students' research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think there should be meetings of three in which each student meets with both professors to discuss his or her research.
Feedback from the instructors and my fellow students on my paper was extremely helpful. I found no weak point of this course.

This was an excellent course. Honestly, I think it should be taught in the first year. It would have been tremendously helpful to me, both professionally and emotionally, to have a course in the first year devoted to moving along a research project. This course helped me feel like I might actually have a chance at being successful at this career.

Strength: not too many irritating deadlines/busy work; chance to glean new insights; time to develop personal research Weakness: class periods not always useful (personally, tho maybe always useful to at least a few ppl?)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a required course for second-year P.h.D. students in political science.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend it. Jacob and Bryan were great. Both of them seemed committed to making this class a place where students felt supported and nurtured. I felt, for the first time since starting the program, like I was in a class where my work mattered and was viewed as important. My experience is that the Ph.D. program feels very isolating, both professionally and socially, and I don't get the sense that the department, as a collective entity, really notices me, or my work, or cares much that I exist (it might be that the department cares very much, I just don't feel that that is communicated to me). This class made me feel like the department did care, and that it would be noticed if I were to not show up to class. I really appreciated that. The class was also very inspiring to me on a professional level, and I feel renewed energy to try to be successful in an academic career.
Yes. If you want, you don't have to put in much effort to the "course" while still putting in serious time into your own workand get feedback from other students (and profs).
